An interesting article on the CNN Belief Blog ...
 
 "Some people think allowing open homosexuality in the military means nothing more than opening a door that was previously closed. It means much more than that. It would mean simultaneously ushering out the back door anyone who disapproves of homosexual conduct, whether because of legitimate privacy and health concerns or because of moral or religious convictions.
 
 This outcome is almost inevitable, because pro-homosexual activists have made it clear that merely lifting the “ban” on openly homosexual military personnel will not satisfy them. The stand-alone bills that have been introduced to overturn the 1993 law, such as S. 3065, call explicitly for:Revision of all equal opportunity and human relations regulations, directives, and instructions to add sexual orientation nondiscrimination to the Department of Defense Equal Opportunity policy and to related human relations training programs.While not in the defense authorization bill amendment approved by the House of Representatives and a Senate committee last week, this goal will undoubtedly be accomplished administratively as part of the “necessary policies and regulations” mandated by that amendment.
 
 This means that all 1.4 million members of the U.S. military will be subject to sensitivity training intended to indoctrinate them into the myths of the homosexual movement: that people are born “gay” and cannot change and that homosexual conduct does no harm to the individual or to society.More at My Take: Ending 'don't ask, don't tell' would undermine religious liberty – Religion - CNN.com Blogs Perkins currently heads up FRC, so he's definitely a conservative. He's a also a Marine veteran.

" ... Twenty-five nations that have transitioned to open service since 1993 insist that lifting such a ban did not lead to the fallout similar to that which critics of a possible US open service have warned about, according to a study by the Brookings Institution, a Washington thinktank that gathered representatives from the militaries in a forum addressing the issue.
 "It's striking that you have an almost universal experience across this 25," including countries whose troops are "still out there with the United States in wars in Iraq and Afghanistan," co-author Peter Singer, director of the institute's 21st Century Defense Initiative, told AFP on Wednesday.
 Singer cited data from the study that showed a lack of a rise in sexual aggression, violence or harassment, no measurable flight from the military, and manageable privacy issues. ..... "

'Ending 'don't ask, don't tell' would undermine religious liberty' 

 
 That's a lie!
 
 From Thomas Jefferson:
 
 "Can the liberties of a nation be thought secure when we have 
 removed their only firm basis, a conviction in the minds of the
 people that these liberties are the gift of God? That they are
 not to be violated but with His wrath?  Indeed I tremble for my
 country when I reflect that God is just; and that His justice
 cannot sleep forever." (Notes on the State of Virginia, 1781)
 
 Washington once noted, "If you remove religious principles from the schools you are going to lose national morality." Amen, George!!
 
 Benjamin Rush, a signer of the Declaration of Independence who was also known as the "Father of Public Schools," once had this to offer: "The only foundation for a republic is...religion. Without it there can be no virtue, and without virtue there can be no liberty."
 
 Don't miss the significance of that last statement: “..without virtue there can be no liberty...."  The principle is clear - a lack of virtue engenders bondage. As one writer noted, "Intemperate men can never be free because their passions give rise to their fetters (bindings)." The more liberties a godless people achieve, the more enslaved they ultimately become in their worldly obsessions.
 
 Still another founding father, the Reverend John Witherspoon, mirrored Benjamin Rush when he declared, "...Civil liberty cannot long be preserved without virtue...."
 
 And finally....
 
 How much liberty did Sodom and Gomorrah have after their Judgment?
 
 Gay sex enslaves the individuals in a prison of sin, and God's Judgment may not be far behind. Same for fornicators, adulterers, etc.

" ... Twenty-five nations that have transitioned to open service since 1993 insist that lifting such a ban did not lead to the fallout similar to that which critics of a possible US open service have warned about, according to a study by the Brookings Institution, a Washington thinktank that gathered representatives from the militaries in a forum addressing the issue.

Easyrider, you literally add nothing useful to the conversation. You're a very poor advocate for your side of the argument because nothing you say can be taken seriously.

Is that 25 godless nations? 25 unbiblical, moraless sewers? The kind you prefer?

 
 Twenty five nations whose troops fight, live, and shower alongside their American allies from time to time. The sky hasn't fallen.

Many seem to want to end DADT for the philosophical point that they want people to be able to be open about their sexuality in the military. 

 I think you have misrepresented the issue. First, this is not an abstract “philosophical” issue. This is a very real problem in which many people's lives are irrevocably harmed and has implications for the strength of our military. Being “open” is not the main issue, which is that soldiers don’t want to get kicked out, or dishonorably discharged and want to be able to do their job without being harassed. Certainly, the freedom to be open about who we are is important, and the psychological price for lying and hiding and “acting straight” is huge, but this is not the central issue. Look, we live in a society that is often not friendly to gays. In every aspect of our lives, you have to modify your behavior depending upon who is around you. Gay folks know it’s not a warm and cuddly atmosphere in the military for the most part, and know how to behave appropriately. “Being open” is a relative concept. 
 
 You seem to be suggesting that hiding one’s homosexuality is some solution. The argument against that is that this has been tried and does not work. People find out or figure it out. It’s really hard to hide one’s sexuality all the time. Folks are being discharged. DADT did not reduce that rate. It hurts gays. It hurts the military. I've looked through most of this thread and the debate seems to be stuck on this whole concern of shared showers. People have made the point that those serving now in the military share showers with those who are gay, and that ignorance is bliss in this situation.
 
 The thing that so many of you seem to be missing is that repealing DADT will not result in an overflow of gays openly serving in the military. From every gay person I have ever spoken to, their issues with DADT is not that they have to serve in the closet, but that they could lose their military career if they are ever convicted of homosexual conduct.

 
 I think the issue raises a larger concern. 
 
 Normally, there are two genders and those genders have certain characteristics (ie, to whom they are attracted). Since attraction is linked to the gender in these categories, if a person has one of any of these traits it is easy to place them into one of the two categories. Now, with homosexuals and transgendered and the like, we run afoul of our categories. To pick on homosexuals, they have the characteristic of the opposite gender and thus do not fit into the pre-established categories. 
 
 So, then, what mental category do they fit? With either? With both? With neither? These questions go to the heart of how and with what we use to form these categories in the first place and I'm not sure anyone really knows the answer. When I ask: "What bathroom is it most appropriate for a homosexual to use" we have to ask ourselves: "how and why is there a division in the first place".

Maybe you religious people should push for separate but equal facilitys as an answer to the elimination of DADT.

 
 Maybe we should create even more facilities so we don't have to look at you.

 They can stay the lower courts order until the appeals court is done looking at the issue. Contrary to Easys uninformed and unintelligent post above, that does not set precedent. The supreme court only sets precedent after hearing a case. Ruling on this does not set any precedent whatsoever. 
 
 In this case, the reason they gave for the stay was that the pentagon was making "Substantial progress" toward putting a program in place to remove the policy on their own. Essentially they ruled that since the pentagon was already working at ending the policy, there was no reason to force a "disorderly transition" by requiring the immediate end to the policy that the court order required.
 
 Contrary to what some of the posters here seem to think, this is NOT a victory for the bigots. It is a victory for those who wanted the policy ended. We dont know exactly what the pentagon has planned (they have not gone public with it) but we DO now know, thanks to the supreme courts ruling, they they have a plan in place to end the ban regardless of anything else.

 When I said they (the Supreme Court) can set a precedent, that assumes they already heard oral arguments, etc. So save your silly "uninformed and unintelligent" slop for your pet carp.
 
 Not only that but you overlooked the following:
 
 By petition for "certiorari before judgment," which permits the Court to expedite a case pending before a lower appellate court by accepting the case for review before the appellate court has decided it. However, Supreme Court Rule 11 provides that a case may be taken by the Court before judgment in a lower court "only upon a showing that the case is of such imperative public importance as to justify deviation from normal appellate practice and to require immediate determination in this Court." 
 
 In addition, "Certain cases that have not been considered by a lower court may be heard by the Supreme Court in the first instance under what is termed original jurisdiction."
 
 Procedures of the Supreme Court of the United States - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

 The appellate court issued an injunction requiring the military to immediately halt its don't ask dont tell policy. This was done on the grounds that the log cabin republicans were likely to win their case. 
 
 The government petitioned the supreme court to stay that injunction (stop it from taking effect).
